Bearer.name: Authorization
Bearer.description: after logging in via `/iam/login` provide the resulting bearer-token as Authorization-header in the form of `'Bearer ' + bearer_token`

IEntity.desciption: The base class for all entities. Dependendingon the specific entity-type you're dealing with, your entity-object may have a lot more properties.

count.description: The total number of entries in the collection

limit.description: The maximum number of entities in this collection

offset.description: The offset that was used to query the resulting collection of entities. A higher offset means you'll get entities that apper later in the datastore.

items.description: not linked to prevent infinite loop

IPublicGetOptions.description: options to query data from the datastore

query.description: not linked because OpenAPI doesn't allow mutli-types, see [swagger-api-issue #236](https://github.com/swagger-api/swagger-parser/issues/236)

IPublicRemoveOptions.description: This interface is defined as `any`. It describes options for removing entities. Although passed down to the datasource_adapter, this object is currently not in use

IPublicSaveOptions.description: This interface is defined as `any`. It describes options for saving entities. Although passed down to the datasource_adapter, the values in this object are currently not in use

reloadAfterSave.description: sets wether the entity should be reloaded after it was saved. If it was a new entity, this would make it be not new, because it now has an id.

channel.description: the channel the message will be published on

msg.description: the content of your message. This in an arbitrary object

options.description: Arbitrary object with additional metadata-options that will be attached to the message

ResultObject.description: An object indicating the success or failure of an action.

StartProcessMessage.description: An object describing the process to start and its initial state

msg.description: An object with the necessary information to identify the process that should be started

options.description: Additional query options for the process you want to start. These options are passed through to the start-method of the processEntity, but aren't used there.

SuccessObject.description: An object indicating the success of an action.

post.summary: Start the execution of a process
post.description: This orders the process engine to start executing a process

parameters.name: start message
parameters.description: The message describing the process to start and its initial state

200.description: ID of the newly started process instance

parameters.name: user_task_id
parameters.description: The ID of the userTask.

get.description: UserTasks can have dynamic parts that depend on the current process. Because of this, they need to be interpreted before they can be displayed, and you can't just get them from the datastore. This route gives you the fully interpreted and processed information you need to display a userTask.

200.description: Fetching the userTask information was successful

post.description: This orders the process engine to execute a process. The difference to `/processengine/start` is, that the process engine will only respond once the process has finished executing. The Response will contain the last state of the processToken, or in other words: The result of the proccess.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The key of the process that should be executed. Either this or the id has to be set.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The id of the process that should be executed. Either this or the key has to be set.

parameters.name: version
parameters.description: The version of the process taht should be executed. If not set, the latest version will be run

200.description: Executing the process was successful. This does not mean, that the process didn't fail. It only means, that ordering the process to start, and waiting for it to end was successful. This does not indicate why the process ended.

schema.description: The last state of the process token when the process ended. This in an arbitrary object, that represents the result of the process.

parameters.name: message
parameters.description: a message that can be published on the messagebus

post.summary: Execute a method on an entity-type-service
post.description: Execute an arbitrary method on an entity-type-service. Entity-type-services are support-classes to manage entities of a certain type. Currently there are only the `NodeInstanceEntityTypeService` and the `ProcessDefEntityTypeService`

parameters.name: className
parameters.description: The name of the EntityTypeService that has the method that should be executed. The currently valid values are `NodeInstance` and `ProcessDef`

parameters.name: method
parameters.description: The name of the method that should be executed

parameters.name: data
parameters.description: An arbitrary object that contains the parameters that should be passed to the method. IF a schema for the method is found, whatever value has the name of the parameter as key will be passed as that parameter. For example when the request-body looks like `{"hello": "world", "test": 123}`, and the method-definition like `myMethod(hello, test, options){ }`, then `hello` will be `'world'` and `test` will be `123` in that method. If no schema is found, the the body will just be passed as the first paramter. In that case `hello` would be `{hello: 'world', test: 123}` and `test` would be `undefined`. The Only parameter you can not define this way is `options`. It will always be parsed from the query-parameter called `query`

parameters.name: query
parameters.description: Whatever is defined here will be passed to the called function as the parameter with the name `options`.

200.description: The value returned by the called method

If no schema is found, the the body will just be passed as the first paramter. In that case `hello` would be `{hello: 'world', test: 123}` and `test` would be `undefined`. The Only parameter you can not define this way is `options`. It will always be parsed from the query-parameter called `query`
